The facts and figures.

Let’s explore how airplane design keeps you safe and flying efficiently.

Length.

Passenger jets typically range from 30 to over 70 meters long. This space isn't just for passengers — it houses avionics, cargo holds, and fuel systems.

Interestingly, fuel is stored in the wings, which helps balance weight and improve aerodynamics. The wings also generate lift — the upward force that keeps the plane in the air — using their specially curved shape called an airfoil.

Wing Span.

Wings can span over 60 meters on large jets, and they're built to be incredibly flexible. This flexibility helps absorb turbulence and reduce stress on the aircraft body.

Despite looking thin, wings are engineered with materials like carbon fiber and titanium and are tested to withstand forces far beyond normal flight. They're nearly impossible to break off under any real-world conditions.

Stabilizers

The horizontal and vertical stabilizers at the tail end control pitch and yaw, helping keep the plane stable and level throughout the flight. They’re critical to balance and control.

Engines

Jet engines are among the most reliable machines ever built. Commercial airliners are designed to fly safely even if one engine stops working — and pilots are trained regularly for these situations.

Most airplanes are also equipped with an APU (Auxiliary Power Unit), which provides backup power on the ground and in emergencies. Redundant systems ensure that even if one system fails, others take over seamlessly.

Modern engines are constantly monitored by onboard computers, and every plane goes through rigorous checks before takeoff. Engine failures are extremely rare — and almost never life-threatening.
